facts: Accused Naresh was married to Raj Kishore (deceased) approximately 6-7 months prior to the incident.
Incident occurred during the night intervening 12th/13th August, 1993.
Raj Kishore was found dead by hanging in her matrimonial home in Village Kathera, P.S. Mauranipur, District Jhansi, U.P.
First Information Report (FIR) was lodged on 13.08.1993 at 7:30 AM by PW1 (Hari Prasad), the father of the deceased.
FIR alleged that Naresh (husband) and his family members (mother, father, brother) used to harass and beat the deceased for dowry (demand of a motorcycle and Rs. 50,000).
Allegation that the deceased was killed by the accused persons due to non-fulfillment of dowry demands.
Post-mortem examination conducted by Dr. V.K. Verma (PW3) on 13.08.1993 at 4:30 PM.
Post-mortem report indicated cause of death as asphyxia due to ante-mortem hanging. A ligature mark was found around the neck. No other significant external or internal injuries were noted.
Investigation conducted by PW4 (Sub-Inspector Ram Mohan).
Charge sheet filed against Naresh (husband), Ram Sewak (father-in-law), Smt. Kanti (mother-in-law), and Suresh (brother-in-law) under Sections 498A and 304B IPC.
Trial Court (Additional Sessions Judge, Jhansi) acquitted all accused persons by judgment dated 22.01.1997.
Trial Court found inconsistencies in the testimonies of PW1 and PW2 (deceased's brother) regarding dowry demands and cruelty.
Trial Court observed lack of evidence to prove cruelty 'soon before death' and noted medical evidence was consistent with suicide.
State of U.P. filed an appeal against the acquittal in the Allahabad High Court.
High Court allowed the appeal partly by judgment dated 29.05.2009.
High Court convicted Naresh (husband) under Sections 304B and 498A IPC, sentencing him to 10 years RI for 304B and 2 years RI plus fine for 498A (sentences concurrent).
High Court upheld the acquittal of the other three accused (father-in-law, mother-in-law, brother-in-law).
High Court relied on the testimonies of PW1 and PW2 regarding dowry demands and invoked the presumption under Section 113B of the Indian Evidence Act.
Naresh filed the present appeal before the Supreme Court challenging his conviction by the High Court.
ipc_sections: Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court correctly reversed the Trial Court's acquittal of Naresh, as the finding of acquittal was perverse and ignored crucial evidence.
precedents: Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415 (Principles for appeal against acquittal)
State of Rajasthan v. Sohan Lal (2004) 5 SCC 573 (Appellate court's power to review evidence in acquittal appeals)
Allarakha K. Mansuri v. State of Gujarat (2002) 3 SCC 57 (When acquittal can be interfered with)
elements: Misappreciation of evidence by Trial Court
Establishment of grounds for reversing acquittal

counter_arguments.loophole: High Court cannot substitute its own view if the Trial Court's view is also a possible one based on evidence. Acquittal strengthens presumption of innocence.
supporting_precedents: Muralidhar @ Gidda v. State of Karnataka (2014) 5 SCC 730 (Acquittal should not be reversed lightly)
Basappa v. State of Karnataka (2014) 5 SCC 154 (High standard for reversing acquittal)
State of U.P. v. Ram Veer Singh (2007) 13 SCC 102 (If two views possible, acquittal view prevails)

prosecution_arguments.argument: All ingredients of Section 304B IPC were established against Naresh: unnatural death within 7 years of marriage, coupled with evidence of dowry-related cruelty soon before death.
precedents: Kans Raj v. State of Punjab (2000) 5 SCC 207 ('Soon before death' does not mean immediately before; requires proximate link)
Rajinder Singh v. State of Punjab (2015) 6 SCC 477 (Essentials of Section 304B and presumption under Section 113B Evidence Act)
Shamnsaheb M. Multtani v. State of Karnataka (2001) 2 SCC 577 (If charge under 304B fails, conviction under 306 IPC possible if abetment proved)
elements: Death otherwise than under normal circumstances
Subjected to cruelty or harassment for dowry

counter_arguments.loophole: Prosecution failed to establish a clear proximate and live link between the alleged dowry demands/cruelty and the death. Evidence regarding cruelty 'soon before' death was vague and contradictory.
supporting_precedents: Surinder Singh v. State of Haryana (2014) 4 SCC 129 (Necessity of proximate link for 'soon before death')
Tarsem Singh v. State of Punjab (2008) 16 SCC 155 (Vague allegations of harassment not sufficient)
Baijnath v. State of M.P. (2017) 1 SCC 101 (Proof of cruelty 'soon before death' is sine qua non for S. 113B presumption)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The testimonies of PW1 (father) and PW2 (brother) regarding dowry demands and harassment were credible and sufficient to establish cruelty under Section 498A and the dowry link for Section 304B.
precedents: State of Punjab v. Gurdeep Singh (1999) 7 SCC 714 (Testimony of close relatives can be relied upon if credible)
Girdhar Shankar Tawade v. State of Maharashtra (2002) 5 SCC 177 (Definition and scope of cruelty under Section 498A)
Trimukh Maroti Kirkan v. State of Maharashtra (2006) 10 SCC 681 (Last seen theory and custodial death implications)

counter_arguments.loophole: PW1 and PW2 are interested witnesses, and their testimonies suffered from material contradictions and improvements, as noted by the Trial Court. Lack of independent corroboration.
supporting_precedents: Harbeer Singh v. Sheeshpal Singh (2016) 16 SCC 418 (Need for caution while evaluating testimony of interested witnesses)
Lallu Manjhi v. State of Jharkhand (2003) 2 SCC 401 (Careful scrutiny required for related witnesses)
Kali Ram v. State of H.P. (1973) 2 SCC 808 (Burden of proof always on prosecution; cannot rely solely on interested testimony if doubtful)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court correctly invoked the presumption under Section 113B of the Indian Evidence Act, shifting the burden onto the accused Naresh to prove his innocence once the foundational facts of Section 304B were established.
precedents: Sher Singh v. State of Haryana (2015) 3 SCC 724 (Nature and operation of presumption under Section 113B)
Pathan Hussain Basha v. State of A.P. (2012) 8 SCC 594 (Once presumption raised, burden shifts to accused)
State of M.P. v. Jogendra (2022) SCC OnLine SC 44 (Reiteration of principles for S. 304B and S. 113B)
elements: Establishment of foundational facts for Section 304B
Failure of accused to rebut the presumption

counter_arguments.loophole: The presumption under Section 113B is rebuttable and does not arise automatically. The prosecution must first conclusively establish the ingredients of Section 304B, especially cruelty 'soon before death', beyond reasonable doubt, which was not done.
supporting_precedents: Baijnath v. State of M.P. (2017) 1 SCC 101 (Presumption contingent on proof of foundational facts)
Raman Kumar v. State of Punjab (2009) 16 SCC 35 (Presumption can be rebutted by accused showing improbability of connection between cruelty and death)
Appasaheb v. State of Maharashtra (2007) 9 SCC 721 (Demand for money for domestic expenses is not dowry demand)

defense_arguments.argument: The prosecution failed to prove the essential ingredient of 'cruelty or harassment soon before death' for dowry demand, which is mandatory for conviction under Section 304B IPC.
edge_cases: Defining the temporal proximity required by 'soon before death'.
Distinguishing general marital discord or unhappiness from specific dowry-related cruelty relevant to S. 304B.
precedents: Kaliyaperumal v. State of Tamil Nadu (2004) 9 SCC 157 (Ingredients of S. 304B, including 'soon before death')
Harjit Singh v. State of Punjab (2006) 1 SCC 463 (Cruelty must be proximate to death; nexus essential)
Surinder Singh v. State of Haryana (2014) 4 SCC 129 (Need for a live and proximate link)

defense_arguments.argument: The testimonies of key prosecution witnesses (PW1 and PW2) were unreliable, inconsistent, and lacked independent corroboration, making them insufficient to form the basis of a conviction.
edge_cases: Reliance on testimony of close relatives in dowry death cases.
Impact of contradictions and improvements on witness credibility.
precedents: Biswajit Halder @ Babu Halder v. State of W.B. (2008) 1 SCC 202 (Credibility diminishes if witness makes improvements)
State of Rajasthan v. Rajendra Singh (2009) 11 SCC 106 (Standard of proof in criminal cases; benefit of doubt)
M. Narsinga Rao v. State of A.P. (2001) 1 SCC 691 (Corroboration for interested witnesses)

defense_arguments.argument: The medical evidence (post-mortem report) indicating death by hanging without other injuries is consistent with suicide and does not support the prosecution's theory of homicide disguised as suicide.
edge_cases: Interpreting medical evidence in hanging cases (suicidal vs. homicidal).
precedents: State of W.B. v. Orilal Jaiswal (1994) 1 SCC 73 (Proof beyond reasonable doubt required even with presumptions)
Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra (1984) 4 SCC 116 (Circumstantial evidence must form conclusive chain)
Ramanand v. State of H.P. (1981) 1 SCC 511 (Medical evidence value depends on consistency with other evidence)

defense_arguments.argument: The High Court erred in reversing the well-reasoned acquittal judgment of the Trial Court, especially when the Trial Court's view was plausible and based on proper appreciation of evidence.
edge_cases: Appellate court's limitations in interfering with acquittal.
Presumption of innocence reinforced by acquittal.
precedents: Muralidhar @ Gidda v. State of Karnataka (2014) 5 SCC 730 (Strong reasons needed to reverse acquittal)
State of Kerala v. K.P. Rao (2011) 6 SCC 450 (Appellate court should be slow to disturb findings of fact based on evidence appreciation by trial court)
C. Antony v. K.G. Raghavan Nair (2003) 1 SCC 1 (Principles governing appeal against acquittal)

judgment.outcome: Appeal Allowed. Conviction by High Court set aside. Accused Naresh acquitted.
reasoning: The Supreme Court found merit in the appeal, agreeing substantially with the Trial Court's assessment of evidence.
The Court held that the prosecution failed to establish beyond reasonable doubt that the deceased was subjected to cruelty or harassment for dowry 'soon before her death'.
Testimonies of PW1 and PW2 were found unreliable due to material contradictions and improvements, lacking sufficient credibility.
The crucial element of a proximate and live link between the alleged dowry harassment and the death was missing.
Medical evidence indicating hanging without other significant injuries was deemed consistent with the possibility of suicide, creating reasonable doubt about homicide.

The High Court was found to have erred in reversing the plausible view taken by the Trial Court, particularly by overlooking the inconsistencies and lack of reliable evidence on the 'soon before death' aspect.
As the foundational facts for Section 304B IPC were not proven beyond reasonable doubt, the presumption under Section 113B of the Evidence Act could not be invoked against the accused.
The acquittal recorded by the Trial Court was restored.
